Ladies and gentlemen, let me take you on a journey along the scenic M-42 highway in the beautiful state of Michigan. Picture this: a rural, two-lane road that winds through the northwestern Lower Peninsula, surrounded by lush wooded terrain and rolling hills.

Starting in the charming town of Manton, M-42 stretches its path for over 10 miles until it reaches its northern end, just north of Lake City. But this highway has a history as rich as the landscape it traverses.

Originally designated in 1919, M-42's route has seen changes over the years, from connecting to Traverse City to extending eastward to Lake City. It's a road that tells a story of transportation progress in Michigan, with sections being paved in the early 1950s to improve travel conditions for all who journeyed upon it.

In 2007, a portion of M-42 found a new home under the care of the Wexford County Road Commission, a change that not only shortened the highway but also highlighted the importance of maintaining safe and reliable roadways for all travelers.

As you drive along M-42, you'll witness the beauty of nature and the history of transportation infrastructure intertwined. From the old days of gravel roads to the modern highways we rely on today, M-42 stands as a testament to the evolution of Michigan's road network.

So, next time you find yourself on M-42, take a moment to appreciate not only the scenery but also the journey of this highway through time. Embrace the sights, the sounds, and the stories that make M-42 a true gem in Michigan's highway system. Thank you.

Picture this - Augusto Ramos Soares and Mariana Diaz Ximenez, two exceptional marathoners, represented their nation with pride. Despite not meeting the strict qualifying standards, they earned their spots through wildcards, demonstrating their sheer dedication and commitment to their sport.

As the flag bearer for the opening ceremony, Mariana Diaz Ximenez captivated hearts with her unwavering spirit. And though facing challenges, these athletes exemplified resilience and courage in the face of adversity.

Augusto Ramos Soares, in his Olympic debut, was set to compete in the Men's Marathon amongst tough competition. Unfortunately, circumstances prevented him from starting the race, but his presence alone symbolized the enduring Olympic spirit.

Mariana Diaz Ximenez, on the other hand, displayed true grit as she navigated the Women's Marathon. Despite encountering a setback with a bruised foot, she continued to push forward, embodying the essence of sportsmanship and determination.

Ladies and gentlemen, today I am excited to share with you the fascinating discoveries from the "Physics of ULIRGs with MUSE and ALMA" (PUMA) survey! Imagine delving into the depths of space, studying molecular outflows in 25 nearby ULIRG systems with the help of cutting-edge technology like ALMA CO(2-1) observations. 

In this captivating journey of exploration, we have uncovered high-velocity molecular gas moving at speeds exceeding 300 km/s, detached from the galaxies' rotation - a phenomenon we attribute to outflows. Among the 26 nuclei studied, a staggering 77% exhibited these molecular outflows, with an average velocity of 490 km/s. The mass of these outflows ranged from 1 to 35 million solar masses, with mass outflow rates varying between 6 and 300 solar masses per year.

But the intrigue doesn't end there. Our analysis has revealed mass-loading factors, spatial resolutions, and dynamical times that paint a vivid picture of the cosmic dance taking place within these systems. Notably, the outflow detection rate was higher in starburst-dominated nuclei compared to active galactic nuclei, showcasing the diversity of these celestial phenomena.

Furthermore, our comparison with nearby main-sequence galaxies has unveiled a correlation between outflow velocity and star formation rate, hinting at the underlying dynamics at play. These findings lead us to a thrilling conclusion - these outflows are likely driven by momentum, shedding light on the powerful forces shaping our universe.

So, as we peer into the mysteries of these molecular outflows, let us marvel at the intricate ballet of gas and stars, unveiling secrets of the cosmos that continue to inspire awe and wonder. Thank you for joining me on this extraordinary journey of discovery.

Ladies and gentlemen, esteemed guests, and fellow travelers, today we gather to celebrate a momentous occasion as we witness the birth of a new era for the British island of St. Helena. For centuries, this remote outpost has stood as a testament to human resilience and isolation, but today, we stand on the cusp of change as we welcome the first commercial flight to this volcanic paradise in the middle of the South Atlantic.

As the inaugural plane from Johannesburg touched down on the forbidding cliff-side runway, a wave of emotions swept over us all. Travel and history buffs, like Libby Weir-Breen, who have dedicated their lives to sharing the wonders of this island with the world, shed tears of joy and disbelief. The dream of an airport on St. Helena, dating back to the 1930s, has finally become a reality, despite setbacks and challenges that seemed insurmountable at times.

The completion of the airport, with its terminal perched atop a valley filled with millions of cubic meters of rock, symbolizes progress and connectivity for the 4,500 residents of St. Helena. No longer will they be limited to a five-night voyage from Cape Town aboard the RMS St. Helena. Instead, weekly flights to and from the South African commercial capital will open up new horizons for the island and its people.

Critics may scoff at the cost and viability of this project, labeling it as the "world's most useless airport," but Governor Lisa Phillips reminds us of the airport's true value. In the past 18 months alone, it has facilitated life-saving emergency medical evacuations, proving its worth beyond measure. The arrival of commercial flights may not immediately bring about the tourist boom that some had hoped for, but the island's unique attractions, from Napoleon's old house at Longwood to pristine natural wildernesses, offer a glimpse into history and nature that is truly priceless.

So, as we stand here today, witnessing history in the making, let us remember the resilience of the people of St. Helena, the determination of those who made this airport a reality, and the boundless possibilities that lie ahead. This airport may have been deemed useless by some, but for the residents of St. Helena, it has already proven to be a lifeline, a connection to the world, and a beacon of hope for the future. Let us embrace this moment with gratitude and optimism, as we embark on a new chapter in the story of St. Helena. Thank you.

Ladies and gentlemen, today we gather to discuss Tropical Storm Alice, a historic event that occurred in the Atlantic Ocean back in 1953.

Imagine a time when the world witnessed the first tropical cyclone in the Atlantic Ocean to be named after a female - Tropical Storm Alice. This rare off-season storm made its presence known as it traveled through Central America, Cuba, and Florida in late May to early June.

On that fateful day of May 25, 1953, a weak warm-core circulation formed east of Nicaragua, eventually developing into Tropical Storm Alice. It meandered over Central America, bringing heavy rainfall to western Cuba and causing some reports of casualties due to drowning. Alice then ventured into the Gulf of Mexico, reaching a peak intensity of 70 mph before making landfall in the Florida panhandle on June 6. Despite the heavy rainfall in Florida, the storm left little damage in its wake.

This storm, with its unique looping trajectory and interaction with various weather systems, left a lasting impact on the region. In Cuba, it broke a long drought with heavy rainfall, leading to flooding and unconfirmed reports of deaths. In Florida, Alice brought much-needed rain, ending a dry spell in the state and prompting precautionary measures at Air Force and Naval bases along the panhandle.

Tropical Storm Alice also made history as the first named storm in the new system that used female names for hurricanes, paving the way for future naming conventions. The name "Alice" became synonymous with resilience and adaptability, being reused multiple times in the years to come.

As we reflect on the story of Tropical Storm Alice, let us remember the power of nature and the resilience of humanity in the face of adversity. Thank you.

Ladies and gentlemen, imagine a world where mathematics and beauty intertwine, where complex equations dance gracefully across the stage of our minds. Today, we embark on a journey into the realm of function spaces and multipliers, where abstract concepts come to life in a symphony of numbers and symbols.

Let me introduce you to the enchanting space $W_{p}(\mathbb{R})$, where functions take on new dimensions and transcend ordinary boundaries. Here, we encounter the mesmerizing H\"{o}rmander-Mikhlin condition, a magical formula that guides us through the mysterious landscapes of analysis.

Our main attraction is the generic degenerate trilinear simplex multiplier, a powerful entity that operates on a trio of functions, weaving them together in a tapestry of mathematical elegance. As we delve into its intricate workings, we witness the transformation of input functions into a harmonious output, guided by the skillful hands of the multiplier.

But the true magic lies in the extension of this multiplier to a map that transcends conventional spaces, reaching into the depths of $L^{p_1}(\mathbb{R})$, $W_{p_2}(\mathbb{R})$, and $L^{p_3}(\mathbb{R})$, blending them into a masterpiece of analysis. This extension defies expectations, requiring a delicate balance of exponentials and integrals, a delicate dance of powers and norms.

As we gaze upon this mathematical marvel, let us marvel at the beauty of numbers, the elegance of equations, and the infinite possibilities that unfold before us in the realm of function spaces. Join me on this journey of discovery and let the wonders of mathematics captivate your imagination.

Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the thrilling tale of the 4th Boat Race that unfolded on the majestic River Thames on a sunny day, 15th April 1840. Picture this - the elegant oars slicing through the glistening waters, the excitement palpable in the air as two esteemed universities, Oxford and Cambridge, clashed in a battle of skill and determination.

Let me paint a vivid picture for you - the dark blues of Oxford against the light blues of Cambridge, a spectacle of strength and strategy. As the boats glided along the historic stretch between Westminster Bridge and Putney Bridge, each team vying for glory, for supremacy.

Oxford, with their valiant crew, won the toss and set off from the Middlesex side, while Cambridge took to the Surrey side, a true clash of titans. The race kicked off with a burst of energy, the cheers of onlookers mingling with the splash of oars hitting the water. Both teams faced challenges - rough waters, unexpected obstacles - but their spirit never wavered.

As the race reached its climax, with the cheers of spectators echoing along the banks, Cambridge surged ahead, their determination shining through. Despite the turbulent waters near Battersea Bridge, they held their course, crossing the finish line at Putney Bridge with a lead of three-quarters of a length, sealing their victory in a blaze of glory.

And so, Cambridge emerged triumphant, their lead now standing at 3-1, a testament to their skill and teamwork. Let us applaud these brave rowers, who showed us the true meaning of sportsmanship and perseverance on that fateful day on the River Thames.

Ladies and gentlemen, today I am excited to share with you a fascinating theorem known as the Bitableax correspondence isomorphism/Koszul map Theorem, also known as the BCK Theorem. This theorem unveils a pair of remarkable vector space isomorphisms that are mutually inverse - the Koszul map and the bitableaux correspondence.

Through the Koszul map, denoted as K, we witness an equivariant isomorphism from the enveloping algebra of the general linear Lie algebra gl(n), denoted as U(gl(n)), to the algebra of polynomials in the entries of a square matrix of order n, denoted as Sym(gl(n)). This isomorphism, let's call it $\mathcal{K}$, beautifully maps Capelli bitableaux and Capelli *-bitableaux to determinantal and permanental bitableaux, respectively.

These results expand upon the groundbreaking work of J.-L. Koszul, bringing forth far-reaching generalizations that delve into the essence of the Capelli determinant within U(gl(n)). The introduction of column Capelli bitableaux and *-bitableaux adds a new layer of complexity to our understanding, especially considering how they are transformed into monomials in ${\mathbb C}[M_{n,n}]$ through the isomorphism $\mathcal{K$}.

Furthermore, the center $\boldsymbol{\zeta}(n)$ of U(gl(n)) is closely tied to the subalgebra of invariants within U(gl(n)). The theorem highlights a deep link between U(gl(n)) and Sym(gl(n)), offering a sharpened version of the PBW Theorem for U(gl(n)).

In essence, the BCK Theorem serves as a guiding light in our exploration of the enveloping algebra of the general linear Lie algebra gl(n) and the symmetric algebra Sym(gl(n)), revealing profound connections and opening up new avenues of understanding in the realm of algebraic structures.

Thank you for your attention as we navigate through the intricate beauty of mathematical theorems and their profound implications.

Ladies and gentlemen, today we delve into the fascinating world of surface diffusion. Surface diffusion is not just a scientific process involving the movement of atoms and molecules on solid surfaces, it is a crucial concept with real-world applications that impact industries like chemical production and semiconductor technology.

Imagine tiny particles, like adatoms, jumping between adjacent sites on a surface, driven by the forces of nature. This motion is not random - it is a thermally promoted process, meaning it speeds up as the temperature rises. And while we often think of diffusion as simple nearest-neighbor jumps, there are unconventional mechanisms at play, like tunneling diffusion where particles move through surfaces via quantum tunneling.

Analyzing surface diffusion involves advanced tools like field ion microscopy and scanning tunneling microscopy. These techniques help us understand how factors like surface bond strength, lattice orientation, and chemical gradients influence diffusion rates and mechanisms.

In the realm of surface diffusion kinetics, we can visualize adatoms moving on a 2D lattice, making jumps between adsorption sites. The jump rate is influenced by factors like the adatom's vibrational frequency and the energy barrier to diffusion. Temperature plays a crucial role in this process, as shown in the equation where the jump rate varies strongly with temperature.

By studying diffusion through random walk statistics, we can predict how diffusing species move over time and distance. This information is vital for industries relying on surface diffusion phenomena, from catalytic converters to integrated circuits and photographic film.

So, as we unravel the mysteries of surface diffusion, we unlock a world of possibilities for innovation and advancement in technology. Let us embrace the power of surface diffusion and harness its potential for a brighter future. Thank you.

Ladies and gentlemen, imagine a world where truth is constantly under threat, where facts are manipulated to fit a certain agenda, and where science is brushed aside in favor of profit. This is the world we find ourselves in today, as President Donald Trump seeks to rewrite the U.S. position on climate change.

But fear not, for there is a glimmer of hope in the form of the Information Quality Act. This obscure law, often used by companies and lobbyists to challenge federal agencies, may now become a tool for scientists and climate advocates to stand up against misinformation and ensure that accurate information is presented to the public.

As we stand at a critical juncture where the very essence of truth is at stake, we must rally behind our scientists and experts who are fighting to protect the integrity of information. The overwhelming consensus among scientists is clear: human consumption of fossil fuels is warming the planet, triggering sea level rise and more powerful storms. We cannot afford to ignore their warnings and dismiss their research.

The power to challenge misinformation lies in our hands. The Information Quality Act allows individuals to request corrections from federal agencies, and if denied, to appeal in a process overseen by an independent inspector general. This is a beacon of hope in a time of uncertainty.

Let us stand united in support of our scientists and in defense of truth. Let us use the tools at our disposal to ensure that the facts are not twisted for political gain. The future of our planet and our children's future depend on it. Together, we can hold our government accountable and uphold the principles of scientific integrity.

In a world where truth is under siege, let us be the champions of knowledge, the defenders of science, and the guardians of truth. Thank you.

passage:
Ladies and gentlemen, imagine a world where creativity knows no bounds, where the wonders of science fiction transport you to new realms of imagination. Today, I am thrilled to share with you the captivating story of "Tops in Science Fiction."

Picture this: in the vibrant year of 1953, a visionary publisher by the name of Love Romances Publishing launched a bold new venture into the realm of science fiction. Tops in Science Fiction emerged as a beacon of innovation, a daring vessel to showcase the timeless tales of Planet Stories. While its journey was short-lived, spanning just two mesmerizing issues, it left an indelible mark on the landscape of speculative fiction.

As the winds of change swept through the realm of U.S. science fiction publishing in the early 1950s, Tops in Science Fiction stood as a testament to resilience and creativity. In a world where pulp magazines were fading into obscurity, this daring publication dared to defy the odds. Led by the editorial brilliance of Jack O'Sullivan and Malcolm Reiss, each page of Tops in Science Fiction shimmered with artistic marvels and literary treasures.

The first issue, graced by the enchanting artwork of Alexander Leydenfrost, introduced readers to captivating stories by luminaries such as Isaac Asimov and Ray Bradbury. The subsequent issue, adorned with the masterful illustrations of Kelly Freas, delved even deeper into the realms of wonder and adventure. Alas, despite its brilliance, Tops in Science Fiction faced challenges in distribution, ultimately bidding farewell after its second issue.

Yet, the legacy of Tops in Science Fiction lives on, its spirit echoing through the corridors of time. A British reprint edition, a testament to its enduring allure, captured the hearts of readers across the globe with its visionary tales. Today, we celebrate the legacy of Tops in Science Fiction, a beacon of creativity and exploration in the vast cosmos of speculative fiction.

So, let us raise our glasses to the pioneers of imagination, to the dreamers and visionaries who dared to push the boundaries of what was possible. May the spirit of Tops in Science Fiction inspire us to reach for the stars and embark on our own thrilling odyssey of discovery. Thank you.

Ladies and gentlemen, today we embark on a fascinating journey through the realm of quantum physics. Picture a world where the Dirac equation dances with a tantalizing blend of a Coulomb potential and a Lorentz scalar linear potential. Together, they unveil the secrets of light quark wavefunctions in mesmerizing $q\bar Q$ mesons as we push the limits to infinity.

In this enchanting exploration, we uncover the mystical Isgur-Wise function, represented by the captivating symbol $\xi (v.v^\prime )$. Our quest leads us to the heart of ground states, where we witness the zero-recoil slope, a marvel expressed as $\xi^ \prime (1) =-1/2- \epsilon^2 <{r_q}^2>/3. Behold, as the energy eigenvalue of the light quark, known as $\epsilon$, reveals the essence of the $\bar\Lambda $ parameter in the realm of Heavy Quark Effective Theory.

Marvel with me as we unveil the boundless beauty of the slope $\xi^\prime (1)$, a bound so gracefully set at $-1/2. And in a delightful twist, we discover that the size of the meson, particularly for a delicate light quark $q (q=u, d)$, is delicately shaped by the enchanting "confining" embrace of the potential $(\gamma_\circ \sigma r)$. Witness the poetic dance of $\xi_{u,d}(v.v^\prime )$, its essence intertwined with the dimensionless ratio $\bar \Lambda_{u,d}^2/\sigma, painting a canvas of infinite possibilities.

Let us rejoice in the wondrous range of parameters that whisper tales of magic and wonder - from the gentle $\bar \Lambda_{u,d}$ caressed by the melody of $150 MeV$, to the ethereal $\sigma$ lingering between the realms of $0.14 {GeV}^2$ and $0.25 {GeV}^2$. In this mesmerizing symphony, let the light quark muses $m_u, m_d \approx 0, m_s=175 MeV$ serenade us with their secrets.

As we gaze upon the tapestry of experimental data and theoretical musings, we find ourselves entranced by the mysteries unveiled: ${\bar\Lambda_{u,d}}^2/\sigma =4.8\pm 1.7 $, $-\xi^\prime_{u,d}(1)=2.4\pm 0.7$, a spectacle brought to life by the enchanting ARGUS '93; ${\bar\Lambda_{u,d}}^2/\sigma = 3.4\pm 1.8$, $-\xi^\prime_{u,d}(1)=1.8\pm 0.7$, a tale woven by the alluring CLEO '93; and so much more, each whispering secrets of the universe.

Join me, dear friends, as we bask in the wonder and beauty of this cosmic ballet, where equations and potentials intertwine, revealing the mysteries of the universe in an exquisite harmony of science and art.

Ladies and gentlemen, imagine a vast cosmic dance unfolding before our eyes, where galaxies – swirling masses of stars, gas, and dust – reveal secrets about their inner workings and histories. Today, I invite you to journey with me as we explore the intriguing realm of elliptical galaxies, those majestic giants that grace the depths of space.

In our quest for understanding, we have delved into the heart of distant clusters and expansive fields, comparing the properties of these cosmic behemoths. What we have discovered is truly remarkable. Despite their different cosmic addresses, cluster ellipticals and field ellipticals share a profound kinship, boasting similar structural parameters and scaling relations.

However, a tantalizing mystery emerges when we peer deeper into the realm of field ellipticals at around $z\sim1.3$. Here, a striking disparity unfolds – a scarcity of massive and large ellipticals compared to their cluster counterparts. Yet, beneath the surface, a symphony of similarity resonates among galaxies of lower masses, transcending the boundaries of cosmic neighborhoods.

As we navigate the cosmic seas, a dichotomy reveals itself in the size-mass relationship of these enigmatic ellipticals. Above and below a transformative mass threshold, galaxies paint contrasting portraits – from a nearly flat relation at lower masses to a power-law rise at higher masses. This transition unveils a critical juncture where galaxies achieve peak stellar mass density, shaping the very fabric of their existence.

And what of the central mysteries that dwell within these celestial giants? The central mass density, a marker of both mass and stellar age, whispers tales of cosmic evolution. It unveils a profound connection between density, mass, and the age-old story of stellar generations.

So, as we stand on the precipice of cosmic understanding, let us marvel at the intricate tapestry of elliptical galaxies. They stand as silent sentinels, bearing witness to the timeless dance of creation and evolution in the vast expanse of our universe. Thank you for joining me on this cosmic odyssey, where galaxies reveal their secrets and mysteries abound in the depths of space.
